facts.text: Appellant was accused No. 1 charged along with accused Nos. 2, 3, 5 and 6

facts.text: On or about July 11, 1953, transferred by sale 10 High Denomination Bank Notes of Rs. 1,000 each to Velji Lakhamshi Joshi for Rs. 1,800

anchor.surface_text: with having on or about July II, 1953, transferred by sale 10 High Denomination Bank Notes of the Denomination of Rs. 1,000 each to one Velji Lakhamshi Joshi for Rs. 1,800 at the rate of Rs. 180 per numbere

facts.text: Offence under s. 7 read with s. 4 of the Ordinance read with s. 109 of the Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: and thus companytravened the provisions of s. 4 of the Ordinance and companymitted an offence punishable under s. 7 of the Ordinance read with s. 109 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Preliminary objection that Ordinance was not in operation on date of offence, overruled by Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection was urged by the learned companynsel for the appellant that the said Ordinance was number in operation at the date when the offence was alleged to have been companymitted and that therefore the prosecution was number maintainable. This objection was overruled

facts.text: Trial ended in conviction of appellant and co-accused

anchor.surface_text: by the learned Presidency Magistrate and the trial ended in the companyviction of the appellant along with the companyaccused of the offence with which they had been charged.

facts.text: Appellant sentenced to fine of Rs. 8,000 and in default six months rigorous imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was sentenced to pay a fine of Rs. 8,000 and in default suffer six months rigorous imprisonment and the companyaccused of the appellant were awarded varying sentences of fine

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Bombay High Court as Criminal Appeal No. 156 of 1955

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took an appeal to the High Court of Judicature at Bombay being Criminal Appeal No. 156 of 1955.

facts.text: State of Bombay filed Criminal Revision Application No. 435 of 1955 for enhancement of sentence

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bombay, the respondent herein, also filed an application for enhancement of the sentence, being Criminal Revision Application No. 435 of 1955.

facts.text: High Court held that appellant transferred 10 High Denomination Bank Notes of Rs. 1,000 each to Velji Lakhamshi

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the learned Presidency Magistrate in regard to the finding of fact and held that the appellant had in fact transferred by sale 10 High Denomination Bank Notes of Rs. 1,000 each to the possession of Velji Lakhamshi

facts.text: High Court overruled contentions that Ordinance had lapsed before July 11, 1953

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also overruled the companytentions which were urged before it in regard to the Ordinance having lapsed and ceased to be in operation before July 11, 1953, the date on which the offence was alleged to have been companymitted.

facts.text: High Court confirmed conviction and sentence of fine Rs. 8,000

anchor.surface_text: It accordingly companyfirmed the companyviction recorded against the appellant by the learned Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate. In regard to the sentence the High Court saw numberground for enhancing the same and companyfirmed the sentence of fine of Rs. 8,000

facts.text: India and Burma Emergency Provisions Act, 1940 passed on June 27, 1940

anchor.surface_text: The India and Burma  Emergency Provisions  Act, 1940, was passed on June 27, 1940 , and was an Act to make emergency provisions with respect to Government of India and Burma.

facts.text: His Majesty's Order in Council 'The India and Burma Termination of Emergency Order, 1946' published on April 1, 1946 declaring emergency ended on April 1, 1946

anchor.surface_text: On April 1, 1946, was published in the Gazette of India Extraordinary His Majestys Order in Council called The India and Burma  Termination of Emergency  Order, 1946 . By the said order the period of emergency referred to in s. 3 of the India and Burma  Emergency Provisions  Act, 1940, was declared to have ended on April 1, 1946.

facts.text: Period specified in s.3 of India and Burma Emergency Provisions Act, 1940 extended from June 27, 1940 to April 1, 1946

anchor.surface_text: The period specified in s. 3 of the said Act thus extended from June 27, 1940, to April 1, 1946.

issues.text: whether the High Denomination Bank Notes Demonetisation Ordinance, 1946 (Ordinance No. III of 1946) promulgated by the Governor-General of India on January 12, 1946, was in operation on July 11, 1953, when the offence under s. 7 read with s. 4 thereof was committed by the appellant herein

anchor.surface_text: special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution raises the question whether the High Denomination Bank Notes Demonetisation Ordinance, 1946 Ordinance No. III of 1946 promulgated by the Governor-General of India on January 12, 1946, was in operation on July 11, 1953

issues.text: whether as soon as the declaration that the emergency was at an end was made on April 1, 1946, the original position was restored and the Ordinance in question which had been promulgated in exercise of the emergency powers ipso facto lapsed when the emergency was declared to have ended

anchor.surface_text: The argument which was addressed before us by the learned counsel for the appellant based on these provisions was (a) that as soon as the declaration that the emergency was at an end was made on April 1, 1946, the original position was restored and the Ordinance in question which had been promulgated in exercise of the emergency powers ipso facto lapsed when the emergency was declared to have ended,

issues.text: whether s. 72 of the 9th Sch. of the Government of India Act, 1935, having been thus restored with effect from April 1, 1946, one must look to its terms as they originally stood to justify the continuance of the ordinance in question after April 1, 1946

anchor.surface_text: (b) that, in the alternative, s. 72. of the 9th Sch. of the Government of India Act, 1935, having been thus restored with effect from April 1, 1946, one must look to its terms as they originally stood to justify the continuance of the ordinance in question after April 1, 1946,

holdings.text: The High Denomination Bank Notes Demonetisation Ordinance, 1946 (Ordinance No. III of 1946) was in operation on July 11, 1953, when the offence under s. 7 read with s. 4 thereof was committed by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution raises the question whether the High Denomination Bank Notes Demonetisation Ordinance, 1946 Ordinance No. III of 1946 promulgated by the Governor- General of India on January 12, 1946, was in operation on July 11, 1953

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.72 GOI Act amended by s.1(3) IBEP Act omitted 6-month limit during emergency period; ordinances became perpetual acts continuing until repealed; no repeal occurred; affirmed by Adaptation of Laws Order 1950 and RBI Act provisions.

holdings.text: Ordinances promulgated under s.72 of the 9th Sch. GOI Act 1935 as amended by s.1(3) IBEP Act 1940 during emergency period are perpetual in duration until repealed, having no time limit.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this appeal turns on the construction of s. 72 of the 9th Sch. of the Government of India Act, 1935 25 and 26 Geo. 5 ch. 42 and s. 1 3 of the India and Burma Emergency Provisions Act, 1940 3 and 4 Geo. 6 ch. 33 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment omitted words 'for the space of not more than six months'; equates to perpetual statutes without duration limit; emergency conditions exercise of power only, not duration; follows J.K. Gas Plant precedent.

holdings.text: Declaration ending emergency on April 1, 1946 did not ipso facto lapse the Ordinance; original position not restored to cause lapse.

anchor.surface_text: The emergency under which the Governor-General was invested with the power to make and promulgate Ordinances for the peace and good government of British India or any part thereof under s. 72 was the condition of the exercise of such power, by the Governor- General and did not impose any limitation on the duration

holdings.reasoning_summary: Emergency is condition precedent for promulgation power only; duration governed by s.72 substantive provisions post-amendment, not tied to emergency continuance.

holdings.text: Post-emergency, s.72 GOI Act terms as originally stood (with 6-month limit) do not apply retrospectively to ordinances promulgated during amended period.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No basis for retrospective operation; duration fixed at promulgation under then-applicable amended s.72 without time limit.

holdings.text: Appellant was rightly convicted as offence under Ordinance validly in force.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal validity of Ordinance established; facts of transfer accepted from lower courts; applies prohibition in s.4 and punishment s.7 r/w s.109 IPC.

precedents.citation: King Emperor v. Benoari Lall Sharma and others 1 1943 F.C.R. 96, 137

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed in support of this contention on the observations of Vardachariar C. J. in King Emperor v. Benoari Lall Sharma and others 1  Legislation by Ordinance has numberdoubt been given the same effect as ordinary legislation and the ambit as to the subject-matter is the same in both cases. But there are two fundamental points of difference which have a material bearing on the present question One is that by the very terms of s.72 of the Ninth Schedule to the Constitution Act, the operation of the Ordinance is limited to a period of

precedents.case_name: King Emperor v. Benoari Lall Sharma and others
precedents.cited_proposition: Ordinance-making power is temporary and limited even if the six-month limit is removed, as it is avowedly for emergency
precedents.cited_holding: by the very terms of s.72 of the Ninth Schedule to the Constitution Act, the operation of the Ordinance is limited to a period of six months and even not it is only temporary, though the particular limit has been removed, and secondly, it is avowedly the exercise of a special power intended to meet an emergency

precedents.citation: King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerjee 1 1944 F.C.R. 1, 12

anchor.surface_text: Zafrulla Khan J. also had expressed himself to the same effect in King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerjee  1  The legislature can at any time enact a measure and such measure can remain in force without any limit of time but the exercise of the Ordinance-making power is limited in two ways  1  by the limitation as to the circumstances in which it can be exercised, and  ii  by the limitation as to the time during which any measure so enacted can remain in operation.

precedents.cited_proposition: Exercise of Ordinance-making power is limited by emergency condition and duration
precedents.cited_holding: the exercise of the Ordinance-making power is limited in two ways (i) by the limitation as to the circumstances in which it can be exercised, and (ii) by the limitation as to the time during which any measure so enacted can remain in operation. The existence of an emergency is a condition precedent to the exercise of the power

precedents.citation: J. K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co., Rampur Ltd. and others v. King Emperor 1 1947 F.C.R. 141, 161

anchor.surface_text: This position was considered by the Federal Court in J. K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co., Rampur Ltd. and others v. King Emperor  1  where Spens C. J. observed- These Ordinances were made under the powers conferred on the Governor-General by s. 72 of the Ninth Schedule to the Constitution Act, as amended by the India and Burma Emergency Provisions Act, 1940  3 4 Geo. 6, Ch. 33 . Under the said s. 72, as it originally stood, Ordinances were limited to an effective life of six months only from the date of promulgation. Sub-section  3  of s. I of the said Act, however, provided that in respect of Ordinances made under s. 72 during the period specified in s. 3 of the Act, s. 72 should have effect as if the words ,for the space of number more than six months from its promulgation were omitted.

precedents.case_name: J. K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co., Rampur Ltd. and others v. King Emperor
precedents.cited_proposition: Ordinances promulgated under s.72 as amended during the emergency period have no time limit on duration and continue until repealed
precedents.cited_holding: Ordinances promulgated under that subsection during the period specified in s. 3 of the Act are subject to no time limit as regards their existence and validity, unless imposed by the Ordinances themselves, or other amending or repealing legislation
